awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Building Partnerships: Documenting the Goals and Outcomes of PEEC and PAGE
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the discipline-based research and instructional collaborations among these institutions and non-TCUP partners expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. This project supports that goal by disseminating the achievements and findings of the colleges that have collaborated in STEM instructional and research capacity-building in two major TCUP strands. 

Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics now represent the largest and most dynamic parts of the curriculum within most of the nation's tribally controlled colleges and universities and other TCUP institutions. Although small and with limited resources,  these colleges are graduating students ready to work or earn graduate degrees in fields across the STEM universe. However, few people working outside of the TCUP community are aware of these accomplishments. The purpose of this work is to document and disseminate the significant impacts, as well as the model design, of two strands of TCUP support:  the Pre-Engineering Education Collaboratives (PEEC) and the Partnerships for Geoscience Education (PAGE).  Dissemination of the knowledge gained through these collaborative efforts will encourage more, and more balanced, collaborations between and among minority- and majority-serving institutions of higher education.  The project aim is to  produce a "partnership" video modeled on recent TCUP videos by conducting on-site interviews and videography, followed by professional editing and finalizing. Dissemination will occur via the Native Science Report, an online journal focusing on STEM education within tribal and Native-serving colleges and universities (nativesciencereport.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Building Partnerships: Documenting the Goals and Outcomes of PEEC and PAGE supported development of a 26-minute professionally produced video examining the goals and outcomes of two NSF-TCUP initiatives, the Pre-Engineering Education Collaboratives (PEEC) and the Partnerships for Geoscience Education (PAGE). Produced by Native Science Report (nativesciencereport.org), an online journal reporting on trends in research and STEM education within Native communities, the video explored how tribal and Native-serving colleges and universities funded through these initiatives successfully developed new programs in pre-engineering and the geosciences by working together and partnering with mainstream universities.

About PEEC and PAGE

The National Science Foundation’s Pre-Engineering Education Collaboratives (PEEC) was a $15 million initiative supporting development of two-year pre-engineering degree programs within the nation’s tribally controlled colleges and Native Hawaiian serving community colleges. Recognizing that many tribal colleges lacked the resources and enrollments needed to support stand-alone engineering programs, the project was conceived as a partnership among tribal colleges regionally, who, in turn, collaborated with one or more mainstream university partners. Working together, these institutions shared courses via distance learning, developed academic enrichment programs, and helped create pathways for students planning to continue their studies at mainstream institutions.
The NSF’s Partnerships for Geoscience Education (PAGE) program, meanwhile, supported collaborations that strengthened programs in the geosciences at tribal colleges. Several tribal and Native-serving colleges, including Northwest Indian College in Bellingham, Washington and Hawaii’s community colleges, have used PAGE awards to develop and strengthen their geoscience-related programs through summer bridge programs and shared research projects. PAGE awards also supported development of articulation agreements, mentoring programs, and student support programs that allow students to pursue geoscience programs within mainstream institutions.

Intellectual Merit

The purpose of the video was to examine how the participating institutions were able to accomplish their goals by building respectful and mutually beneficial partnerships. While federal agencies and private foundations often encourage or mandate collaboration between colleges and universities, efforts to promote “partnerships” between mainstream and Native institutions too often place tribal colleges in a subordinate and, frequently, largely symbolic, position. Assuming that mainstream universities should be the lead institutions, tribal colleges are often treated as afterthoughts, useful for the purpose of securing a grant, but not treated as knowledgeable colleagues or equal contributors. The video examined how tribal, Native-serving, and mainstream institutions avoided these pitfalls by nurturing a partnership of equals, with the expectation that resources will flow both ways and the expertise of tribal leaders will be acknowledged.

Broader Impacts

Sharing the completed video, without cost, through Native Science Report increases awareness of the Pre-Engineering Education Collaboratives and the Partnerships for Geoscience Education. While the outcomes of PEEC and PAGE are reported in annual and final reports submitted to the NSF, there is little familiarity with the initiatives outside of the tribal college community. By documenting the goals, implementation strategies, and outcomes of both programs, the video highlights the merits of NSF-TCUP’s collaborative model, encouraging its use in future NSF initiatives and possible adoption by other agencies and grant-making institutions. By disseminating information about new degree programs and new instructional practices, the video encourages discussion and replication of promising practices in STEM education, which has the potential to enrich all of American higher education.



Last Modified: 01/17/2024
Modified by: Paul Boyer

Image
  • The Building Partnerships video can be viewed at https://nativesciencereport.org/2023/05/building-partnerships-in-stem-education/
